The '''Valparaiso Crusaders Basketball''' team is the basketball team that represent [[Valparaiso University]] in [[Valparaiso, Indiana|Valparaiso]], [[Indiana]]. The school's team currently competes in the [[Horizon League]]. The team last played in the [[NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament]] in [[2004 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|2004]]. The Crusaders are currently coached by [[Bryce Drew]], who is in his 1st year. Bryce replaced his father, Valparaiso coaching legend [[Homer Drew]], in May of 2011. The Crusaders play in the [[Athletics-Recreation Center]], which has a capacity of 5,432.
==History== ===The beginning=== The Crusaders' first game was in [[1917 in sports|1917]]. Under the coaching of [[Sidney Winters]], the team lost to Chicago. The team would finish 7-2 that year [http://www.valpo.edu/athletics/assets/mediaguides/MBB-2006-2007-01.pdf]. In 1988, Homer Drew took the job as head coach and remained until retiring in May 2011. He was then succeeded by his son Bryce. 1988 would also be the year that the Crusaders defeated Number 19 Notre Dame in a game that came to be known as "The Lutheran Miracle."
===The tallest team=== The [[1944 in sports|1944]]-[[1945 in sports|1945]] team was billed as "The World's Tallest Team."[http://www.valpo.edu/athletics/assets/mediaguides/MBB-2006-2007-01.pdf] That year, they defeated [[Long Island University]] in a game played in [[Madison Square Garden]].
===Conference affiliation=== The Crusaders would join the [[Indiana Collegiate Conference]] for the [[1950 in sports|1950]]-[[1951 in sports|1951]] season. The Crusaders advanced to the NCAA tournament for the first time in [[1961 in sports|1961]]-[[1962 in sports|1962]]. In [[1968 in sports|1968]]-[[1969 in sports|1969]], they hosted an NCAA tournament game for the first time.
===Division I=== The Crusaders joined Division I before the [[1978 in sports|1978]]-[[1979 in sports|1979]] season. After four years as an independent, they became charter members of the [[The Summit League|AMCU]].
===NCAA tournament=== Under coach [[Homer Drew]], the Crusaders became a conference power. They won their first Mid-Continent championship in [[1995 in basketball|1995]], led by star player [[Bryce Drew]]. However, the team was not invited to the [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|NCAA Tournament]]. The Crusaders won the [[1996 in basketball|1996]] conference championship and received their first invitation to the Division I NCAA Tournament. In the [[1998 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|1998 Tournament]], the Crusaders won their first Tournament game, defeating the [[University of Mississippi]] on [[the Shot (Valparaiso University)|a last second shot]] by Bryce Drew. The Crusaders would go on to win their second round game against [[Florida State University]] before losing in the Sweet 16 to the [[University of Rhode Island]]. The Crusaders would win the Mid-Continent Conference's automatic bid to the NCAA Tournament every year until [[2001 in basketball|2001]], when [[Southern Utah University]] won the conference tournament. In Coach [[Scott Drew]]'s only year as head coach, the team advanced to the [[2003 National Invitation Tournament|National Invitation Tournament]] where they lost to the [[University of Iowa]] in their first game televised by [[ESPN]]. They would play in the title game of the Mid-Continent Conference Tournament every year between [[1995 in basketball|1995]] and [[2004 in basketball|2004]].
